description: Melissa Martin Ellis was Creative Director and Vice President of Millennium Publications. She is an artist, photographer and writer. Her paintings and photos have appeared in numerous New England exhibits and galleries, as well as in print media such as The Redwood Review, Newport This Week, Newport Life Magazine, Haunted Newport, The Boston Globe, The Providence Journal, Horseman’s Yankee Peddler and Balancing the Tides literary magazine.She and her husband, author Mark Ellis collaborated on the writing of The Everything Guide to Writing Graphic Novels from Adams Media, was published in December 2007. Her book on photography, The Everything Guide to Photography, 2nd Ed.was published in the fall of 2007.
name: Melissa Martin-Ellis

deck: Earl Mach Rauch is the co-creator and writer of Buckaroo Banzai. He currently is writing the new Buckaroo comics being published by Moonstone.
name: Earl Mac Rauch

deck: Credited as an assistant penciler on X-Men #373.
name: Rob Jensen

deck: Brad Rader is an artist who has worked in comics and animation.
name: Brad Rader

deck: Writer/penciller, he created Cedric, with Raoul Cauvin.
description: He started his career working very closely with Mittéï, who helped him find his place at Spirou magazine. He has drawn the backgrounds in two issues of Natacha. He has also worked in L'an 40 and Taxi Girl.
name: Laudec

deck: Editor on the Cinder and Ashe series.
name: Pat Bastienne

deck: Comic Creator - an Italian comic-book artist...
name: Sergio Ponchione

deck: Writer and lead singer of the glam band, The Scissor Sisters
name: Ana Matronic

deck: He has worked as a penciller, inker and cover artist in "Soda". He collaborated with Janry in "Le petit Spirou".
description: Bruno Gazzotti got his passion for comc books reading "Spirou", "Tintin", "Gaston Lagaffe" and "Natacha". He started working for the "Spirou" magazine after showing some of his drawings to Patrick Pinchart. He worked along with Janry and Tome in "Le petit Spirou" and finally gave up his studies in art. Tome will keep working with him in "Soda" when Warnant left after two issues. He travels to New York and makes thousands of photographies to get the right atmosphere for this one. "Soda" was a sucess and the confirmation of his talent.
name: Bruno Gazzotti

deck: The work of Mitch Foust is mostly black & white portraiture of Marvel characters. Lately though, he has been working in colors
name: Mitch Foust

deck: Has written Comics for Now Comics.
name: James Bradshaw

deck: London born writing extraordinaire Gary Whitta has, written for video games and magazines, he also wrote a screenplay. Oh and at some point he wrote a comic.
name: Gary Whitta

deck: Artist and older sister of Jo Chen
name: Christina Chen

deck: Artist and designer known for his work in DC Comics animation.
description:
His credits include charcater designing on Batman: The Animated Series, art director on Superman: TAS, Justice League and Batman Beyond.
 
He was also the producer for Teen Titans and The Batman in which he was also an art director.
name: Glen Murakami

deck: Janet L. Hetherington is a comic book creator and journalist. She self-published the Eternal Romance comic book series in 1997 under her best Destiny imprint, wrote the Elvira: Mistress of the Dark comic book for Claypool Comics for six years, has contributed to Amazing Heroes, Combo, Animation magazine, Animation World Network, The Pulse, Comics Buyers' Guide and PopCultureAddict.com among others and is former managing editor of WizardWorld.com.
description:
Background and Education

Janet L. Hetherington was born in Toronto, Canada, and grew up in the small town of Wallaceburg, Ontario. She discovered science fiction and comic books at an early age, and was especially drawn to DC Comics characters – Superman, Supergirl, Batman, Wonder Woman, Green Lantern, Flash and the Legion of Super-Heroes as well as all the DC romance and mystery titles.

Janet started writing and drawing comics as a teen-ager, and created a teen hum or comic strip called Sweet Caroline for The Grapevine high school newspaper.
 
Janet says that she was inspired by Lois Lane and upon graduating high school, att ended Carleton University in Ottawa (Canada’s capital) to study journalism. While at Car leton, Janet became involved in organizing Ottawa’s Maplecon science fiction and comic book conventions. She also began writing for Fantagraphics’ comics-themed publication Amazing Heroes. Janet was assigned the “Canadian beat,” and interviewed many Canadian creators, including artist Ronn Sutton.

After graduating from Carleton, Janet stayed in Ottawa and took a job as copy editor with Canadian Consumer magazine (the Canadian equivalent of Consumer Reports). She was later promoted to associate editor. Janet left Canadian Consumer to take a job with Canada Post, where she worked for 11 years in stamp marketing and promoted Canada’s postage stamps worldwide.

In 1994, Janet left Canada Post to become a freelance writer and editor. By that time, Ronn Sutton had moved to Ottawa from Toronto and the couple formed Hetherington/Sutton Studio. Janet and Ronn co-created the newspaper strip Jannie Weezie, which was briefly published by the Ottawa Citizen. The strips were collected into two booklets: The Jannie Weezie Ashcan Sampler and Jannie Weezie vs. the Brain.

In 1995, Janet and Ronn worked on Canada’s super-hero stamp issue, which featured Superman, Captain Canuck, Nelvana, Johnny Canuck and Fleur de Lis. Janet wrote and Ronn illustrated an associated Canada Post comic book, Perf and Gauge, in 1996.

At the height of the “bad girl” boom, Janet and Ronn collaborated on a number of projects for Millennium Comics, including co-creating the spider-vampire character Spinnerette.

In 1997, Janet self-published Eternal Romance under her Best Destiny imprint. That same year, Janet served as a judge for the Will Eisner Comic Industry Awards. Janet and Ronn were art guests of honor at the Con*Cept science fiction convention in Montreal.

Eternal Romance was featured in two books by author Trina Robbins: From Girls to Grrlz: A History of Women's Comics from Teens to Zines; and The Great Women Cartoonists.

Janet continued writing and editing professionally and, in 1998, began a long association with the Canadian Toy Testing Council as Editor of its annual Toy Report.

In 1999, Janet won a Prix Aurora Award for excellence in Canadian science fiction and fantasy for her work as co-curator of “60 Years of Superman” at the Nepean Museum in Ottawa.

In 2000, Janet began scripting for Elvira: Mistress of the Dark, published by Claypool Comics. Ronn Sutton was a key artist penciling the book, and following a lunch meeting with editor Richard Howell, Janet was able to successfully pitch some Elvira story ideas. Janet continued writing both back-up and lead stories for six years.

In 2002, following the sale of the WizardWorld.com website by Wizard Entertainment to a high-tech company with offices in Ottawa, Janet became managing editor of WizardWorld.com. When the high-tech bubble burst, the company went bankrupt and Janet returned to freelancing. (WizardWorld.com has since reverted back to Wizard Entertainment.)

In 2005, Janet took as job as an editor with the Canadian Food Inspection Agency, where she currently works as a communications advisor in its Public Affairs Branch.

In 2007, during the 10-year anniversary of Eternal Romance, Janet joined forces with Arrow Publications LLC to bring color versions of the comics to the web at MyRomanceStory.com. Janet also wrote a romance comics novella for Arrow called “Dangerous Seductions.”

Janet entered a new comics creation, Monster Love, into Platinum Studios’ 2008 Comic Book Challenge competition. Monster Love made the Top 50 and later placed third in the Starz Character Idol pitching competition held at the 2008 Ottawa International Animation Festival.

Janet won a Judges' Choice Blue Ribbon Award for her art piece, The Witch's Witchblade at the 2009 World Science Fiction Convention in Montreal. Her poem "The Zombie Flu" was published in the poetry anthology, Vicious Verses and Reanimated Rhymes.

In 2010, Janet’s Eternal Romance series is being offered for download as Apple apps for iPhone and iPad via Arrow Publications LLC.

While Janet still loves writing and drawing comics, she has recently turned to crafting screenplays as well as comics.

Comics Journalism

Janet Hetherington has written for:

  • Amazing Heroes
  • Parsec
  • Comics Buyer’s Guide
  • Combo
  • Wizard Magazine
  • Animation Magazine
  • WizardWorld.com
  • Animation World Network
  • VFXWorld.com
  • The Pulse
  • PopCultureAddict.com
name: Janet L. Hetherington

deck: The artist of Marvel Digital Exclusive - Astonishing Tales: Daredevil
name: Martin Redmond

Also works with Boom!Studios doing Disney covers and some interior work including the Darkwing Duck 2011 Annual.
